channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Huge Fire Shuts Down Nairobi’s International Airport
item.description: The blaze was contained after several hours and the airport was partly reopened for domestic and cargo flights, but international traffic was still suspended.
item.dc:creator: By REUBEN KYAMA and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Letter from China: Fault Lines Laid Bare in Hong Kong
item.description: A schoolteacher's outburst at a demonstration has highlighted deep divisions in the city, over issues like freedom of speech and the need to accommodate Beijing's authority.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Yemen, on Alert for Terrorism, Claims It Foiled a Qaeda Plot
item.description: Yemeni security officials said that they had thwarted a plot to kidnap or kill foreigners working at an oil terminal, but the claim aroused skepticism among terrorism analysts.
item.dc:creator: By NASSER ARRABYEE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A Yemeni police officer patrolling Sana International Airport on Wednesday.

item.title: China Fines Milk Powder Suppliers Over Pricing
item.description: The punishment comes at a time when Chinese parents have gone to great lengths to buy foreign-made infant milk powder.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN and EDWARD WONG

item.title: No Deal Between Army and Islamists in Egypt
item.description: Egypt’s interim president said Wednesday that diplomats had failed to broker an agreement to end the country’s five-week-old political crisis.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Obama Cancels Putin Meeting as Snowden Adds to Strains
item.description: The move reflects frustration with the Russian government for refusing to send Edward J. Snowden to the United States to face charges of leaking national security secrets.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, at a meeting in Northern Ireland in June.

item.title: The Lede: Video of Iran’s New President on Nuclear Talks
item.description: Video of Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, saying the dispute over the his country’s nuclear program could be resolved “not in the distant future but very soon.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: August 7
item.description: An elephant hit by a train, about 85 miles east of Guwahati, Assam.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Flowers offered by villagers, seen on the body of an elephant, which was hit by a train about 85 miles east of Guwahati, Assam.

item.title: India Ink: Border Clashes Between India and Pakistan Continue
item.description: A second day of violent skirmishes is leading to concerns about worsening tensions along the Indian-Pakistani border in Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: An Indian Army soldier posted close to the Line of Control, the disputed border dividing the Kashmir region between India and Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Syrian Army Kills Scores of Rebels in Ambush
item.description: Government forces attacked a group of insurgents near the Syrian capital, Damascus, killing more than 60, according to both state media and rebels.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD, HWAIDA SAAD and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Japanese Government to Help Stabilize Nuclear Plant After Leaks
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called for the intervention Wednesday as concern grew over new contamination from the Fukushima Daiichi plant into the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Members of a Fukushima panel inspecting the construction of a barrier that is meant to stop contaminated water from leaking.

item.title: Chinese Judges Disciplined for Cavorting With Prostitutes
item.description: A businessman angry at a judge trailed the judge and his colleagues to capture incriminating footage, which showed them with prostitutes at a glitzy nightclub.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: North Korea to Reopen Shared Industrial Complex
item.description: The North’s announcement about the Kaesong complex signaled a thaw in relations with South Korea after increasing pressure on the North from China to modify its behavior.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: South Korean workers and owners who run factories in the shuttered Kaesong industrial complex staged a rally on Wednesday near the border village of Panmunjom to ask for the resumption of operations at Kaesong.

item.title: India Ink: Soccer Dreams of Tibetan Exiles
item.description: Tibetan exiles assemble a soccer team without a country.
item.dc:creator: By RADHIKA OBEROI
item.media:credit: Courtesy Tibetan National Sports Association Archives
item.media:description: The Tibetan football team in Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh, during the All India Shaheed Durga Mall Dal Bahadur Memorial Gold Cup 2010.

item.title: Big Fire Closes Nairobi Airport; Flights Rerouted
item.description: A large fire engulfed the arrivals hall at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi early Wednesday, forcing its closure and the rerouting of all inbound flights.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A large blaze forced the closure on Wednesday of Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: China Fines 6 Milk Suppliers in Price-Fixing Probe
item.description: China announced Wednesday that it had fined six milk suppliers, including Mead Johnson and New Zealand’s Fonterra, a total of $108 million for price-fixing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Brunete Journal: Special Delivery, of Sorts, for Wayward Dog Owners
item.description: In its battle to get dog owners to clean up after their pets, a town in Spain found vast improvement by boxing up a vivid reminder for wayward residents.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pet owners in Brunete, Spain, where volunteers stealthily mailed residents vivid reminders to clean up after their dogs.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Bomb Blast Kills 11 at Soccer Field
item.description: A bomb blast that appeared to be targeting a provincial government minister killed 11 people before dawn on Wednesday at a soccer field in Karachi, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Court Finds Soldiers Killed 6 at Temple
item.description: A Thai court said Tuesday that soldiers killed six people in 2010 at a Buddhist temple during the military crackdown on antigovernment demonstrators in Bangkok.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: 4 Men Sentenced in Neo-Nazi Killing Spree
item.description: A Hungarian court sent four neo-Nazis to prison on Tuesday for killing Roma families in a spree of racist violence in 2008 and 2009.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Gas Leak Causes Deadly Residential Blast
item.description: Twelve people died and at least 60 more were injured, officials said Tuesday, in an explosion in the center of Rosario, Argentina’s third-largest city, with 1.2 million people.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tycoon’s Prison Sentence Is Cut by Two Months
item.description: Russia’s Supreme Court on Tuesday reduced by two months the sentence of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon and political opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Dozens Die in Car Bombings in the Baghdad Area
item.description: A series of car bombs targeting busy markets and shopping streets in and around Baghdad killed at least 51 people and wounded more than 100 on Tuesday, Iraqi medical and police sources said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Charges Libyan Militia Leader in Benghazi Attack
item.description: The militia leader, Ahmed Abu Khattala, has denied any role in the attack on Sept. 11, 2012, which killed the United States ambassador to Libya and three other Americans.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: At War Blog: Crackling Over the Radio, Spotter’s Voice Guides Syrian Rebels
item.description: A man nicknamed the Watchtower leads a network of rebel spotters in northern Syria who watch roads and military bases, broadcasting warnings about the movement of government forces.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Rebels credit Mudar Abu Ali with warning of dangers and alerting fighters to potential targets.
